I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  Country  Programming  Midterm  Review  Mission  in  April  2007,  the 
Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  confirmed  its  request  for  technical 
assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for a Transport Information System.1 
An ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC on 26–29 June 2007 and discussed with officials 
of the Government the use of an information system to increase capacity, efficiency, and quality 
of road transport. This report is based on the understanding reached with the Government on 
the scope and output of the TA, cost estimates, a financing plan, consultants’ terms of reference, 
and implementation arrangements. 
 
II.  ISSUES  
2.  The development of expressways and other road networks has contributed greatly to the 
PRC’s economic development. Rapid economic growth has changed the structure of urban 
areas, which contribute 80% of the gross domestic product (GDP). Urban areas have been 
changed, not only by economic development but also by migration from the rural areas. In a 
single generation, 300 million to 400 million people have moved from the countryside to the city. 
The urban share of the total population grew from 26% in 1990 to almost 40% in 2005. This shift 
brought suburban development to many cities, making biking and walking less feasible and 
rapidly increasing the number of people who need an efficient public transport. The continuing 
shift to private cars with urbanization is causing the quality of service and efficiency of public 
transport to deteriorate.  
 
3.  Rapid economic growth also brings increased freight traffic. Highway freight traffic is 
increasing at almost the same rate as GDP growth, or about 10% per annum from 2003 to 2006. 
The total length of the expressway network increased by 20% from 2004 to 2005 and by 9.5% 
from 2005 to 2006. During that time the total length of roads other than expressways increased 
by just 5% annually. Freight transport, especially interprovince and international traffic, relies 
heavily on the expressway network, but total road investment has lagged behind the growth of 
freight transport. Logistical costs (transport, warehousing, administration, and inventory) are 
thought to account for 30–40% of the total cost of manufactured goods in the PRC, much more 
than the 5–20% in the United States. Expanding the expressways is not catching up to the 
demand  of  freight  transport.  To  ensure  efficient  and  reliable  freight  transport  and  public 
transport, new measures are required.  
 
4.  In parallel with economic growth, the number of vehicles on the roads has grown rapidly. 
With development, the PRC has become the world’s second largest oil consumer and the 
world’s largest carbon dioxide-emitting country in 2006. Vehicles account for about 30% of the 
total oil consumption in the PRC, and this amount is projected to reach 57% in 2020. Without 
increasing the efficiency of transport, transport in the PRC would contribute to worsen the 
issues of energy security and the environment, both locally and globally. 
 
5.  In response to the issues and the emerging demand for road transport, the Government 
is keen to increase the capacity and efficiency of road transport by utilizing newly available 
technology.  In  many  businesses  and  governments  around  the  world,  the  construction  and 
operation  of  transportation  systems  are  being  transformed  by  computers,  sensors,  and 
communications technology—collectively called information technology (IT). The application of 
IT to surface transportation is called intelligent transport system (ITS). ITS provides the ability to 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 24 April 2007.

2   
gather, organize, analyze, use, and share information about transportation systems. In the 
modern world, this ability is crucial to the effective and economical operation of transportation 
systems and to their efficient use. Not only IT can be very helpful in conceiving, planning, and 
building  new  parts  of  the  transport  system;  ITS  also  provides  vital  support  in  operating 
transportation systems, including traffic management, oversight of system maintenance, and 
more effectively and reliably managing public transport. The support provided by ITS helps 
increase the capacity of existing road infrastructure, efficiency of road transport, and quality 
transport service. 
 
6.  The Ministry of Communications (MOC) started research and development of ITS in the 
1990s and developed the ITS strategic program. In the past decade, MOC in cooperation with 
related organizations deployed a few ITS applications such as electronic toll collection and 
weather information service. In the 11th Five-Year Plan (11FYP) (2006–2010), the Government 
stated that it would continue with ITS deployment to improve transport service, infrastructure 
management, and national economic development, specifically (i) to promote integration of the 
electronic information network with physical infrastructure to maximize the efficiency, safety, and 
utilization of infrastructure, and to make road transport a link to encourage the integration of 
transportation  modes  for  different  users  with  more  choices;  (ii)  to  relieve  congestion  and 
increase the capacity of the transportation system by providing information for transportation 
system operators and road users, and to minimize new infrastructure construction; and (iii) to 
minimize the probability and severity of collisions, respond to and handle accidents faster, and 
reduce accident losses to the extent possible. To achieve the objective in 11FYP, MOC is 
focused  on  developing  a  travel  information  service  system  (TISS)  as  one  of  the  strategic 
programs in the road transport sector at the moment. TISS will provide various information 
supporting traveler decisions on intended trips: information about routes, traffic situation and 
destination  before  and  during  the  trips.  Information  provision  with  TISS  will  increase  the 
efficiency of road transport and the use of the existing road infrastructure.  
 
7.  Over 2005–2006, TISS has been initiated in five demonstration provinces/cities, each of 
which started to establish its own TISS. However, there is neither a uniform standard for 
information service and operation mode nor an information-sharing system. MOC requested TA 
to establish standards for TISS. Without a proper standard and an information-sharing system, 
interoperability between TISS in different areas/cities and expansion to new areas cannot be 
attained. By specifying how the standard would promote interoperability and expandability and 
what are the required standards for TISS, TISS will be introduced using a systematic and 
economical approach. Standardization will have a good effect: it will open markets, encourage 
competition, and ensure integration, quality, and efficiency as well. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The expected impact of the TA is increased capacity of the existing road infrastructure, 
an  efficient  road  transport,  and  quality  transport  service.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  is 
recommendations on how the PRC should deploy ITS and TISS, assistance to MOC to develop 
a standard architecture framework of TISS, and implementing and operating guidelines.  
 
9.  The outcomes will be achieved by (i) reviewing the current status of ITS in the PRC 
including  existing  strategies,  policies,  and  plans  on  ITS,  and  related  laws,  regulations, 
institutions, and standards; (ii) reviewing systems similar to TISS in developed countries; (iii) 
identifying key issues and recommendations; (iv) preparing recommendations for PRC’s ITS

3
and  TISS;  (v)  preparing  a  standard  architecture  framework  of  TISS;  (vi)  preparing  TISS 
implementing and operating guidelines; (vii) building capacity through workshops and training 
programs;  and (viii) disseminating the results through publication for related agencies and 
stakeholders. The design and monitoring framework outlining the expected impact, outcomes, 
outputs, and activities is in Appendix 1.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  International and national consultants will be engaged to help the Government study the 
transport information system. They will also assist MOC to develop recommendations on how 
the  PRC  should  deploy  ITS  and  TISS,  a  standard  architecture  framework  of  TISS,  and 
implementing and operating guidelines. The TA will be carried out in close consultation with 
provincial governments and the central Government agencies concerned and will take into 
account  all  previous  studies  carried  out  by  the  Government,  ADB,  and  other  multilateral 
agencies,  as  well  as  best  international  practice.  The  TA  will  involve  fieldwork,  gathering 
international  experience,  analytical  research,  stakeholder  consultations  with  national  and 
provincial  governments  and  agencies  responsible  for  road  transport  and  road  users,  and 
training for building the capacity of government staff to implement the TA outputs.  
 
11,  The TA will include case studies that exemplify typical issues in the PRC regarding 
deployment of TISS. MOC and ADB will select from five demonstration provinces/cities (para. 7) 
subjects for the case studies, which are making progress and willing to cooperate with the TA. 
The selected provinces should be cooperative and have sufficient information and data for their 
particular case study. The case studies will entail in-depth study of the current state and key 
issues. The case studies will also apply developed standard architecture framework of TISS and 
implementing and operating guidelines.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. It will be financed as a 
grant from ADB’s TA funding program. The Government requested ADB to finance $400,000. 
MOC will finance the remaining $100,000 equivalent, which will cover office accommodation 
and counterpart staff required to implement the TA. The detailed cost estimate is in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The TA will require about 34 person-months of consulting services (4 international and 
30 national) including fieldwork spread over a period of 8 months. A national consulting firm in 
association  with  an  international  consultant  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  using  the  simplified 
technical proposal procedures and quality- and cost-based selection method on the quality-cost 
ratio of 80 to 20 in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). The international consultants will provide expertise in ITS. The 
national  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  (i)  road  planning;  (ii)  ITS,  especially  system 
architecture; (iii) road and traffic information database; and (iv) transport standard/regulation. A 
national ITS expert will be the team leader and an international consultant will be the deputy 
team leader. Appendix 3 presents the outline terms of reference for the consultants.  
 
14.  MOC will be the Executing Agency. It will be responsible for guiding and supervising the 
TA activities and for coordinating with relevant Government agencies and organizations. MOC 
will (i) ensure cooperation of the concerned Government agencies, and (ii) provide guidance 
and assistance to the consultants in implementing the TA. To develop capacity, the consultants

4   
will (i) develop and implement a domestic training program, and (ii) identify suitable international 
training opportunities and coordinate and arrange international training. The TA is expected to 
begin  in  March  2008  and  be  completed  by  October  2008.2 The  international and  national 
consultants will also conduct workshops for consultation with stakeholders and dissemination of 
information. MOC will provide the consultants with all relevant materials, recent studies, and 
reports required for the TA. The consultants will maintain close contact with MOC and ADB and 
will keep them informed of the TA progress and findings. A tripartite meeting of the Government, 
ADB staff, and the consultants will be held to elicit comments on a draft final report and guide 
the consultants in finalizing it. Equipment provided under the TA will be procured in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and will be handed 
over to MOC upon completion of the TA.  
 
15.  The consultants will submit the following reports to ADB and MOC as scheduled in the 
design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1): (i) a list of sources of information, a list of 
related regulations, and a list of related organizations and contact persons, 2 weeks after the 
start of the services; (ii) an inception report, including an outline of the final report, 4 weeks 
following the start of the services; (iii) an interim report 16 weeks after the start; (iii) a draft final 
report within 26 weeks of the start; and (iv) a final report 2 weeks after receiving all comments 
from MOC and ADB. The consultants will hold a stakeholder consultation workshop within 8 
weeks of the start of services, and a national workshop in Beijing, within 4 weeks of the 
submission of the draft final report, to disseminate TA findings. The inception report, interim 
report, draft final report, and final report―three copies of each (in English and Chinese)―will be 
submitted  to  ADB,  MOC,  Ministry  of  Finance,  and  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission. A draft outline of the consultant’s final report is in Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Transport Information System, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The  expected  impact  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  increased  capacity  of  the 
existing road infrastructure, efficient road transport, and quality transport service. The objectives 
are to assist the Ministry of Communications (MOC) in developing a standard architecture 
framework for a travel information service system (TISS) and implementing/operating guidelines.  
 
2.  The TA will (i) review the current status of the intelligent transport system (ITS) in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) including existing strategies, policies, and plans for ITS and 
related laws, regulations, institutions, and standards; (ii) review systems similar to TISS in 
developed  countries;  (iii)  identify  key  issues  and  recommendations;  (iv)  prepare 
recommendations for PRC’s ITS and TISS; (v) draft a standard architecture framework for TISS; 
(vi) draft TISS implementing and operating guidelines; (vii) carry out capacity building through 
workshops  and  training  programs;  and  (viii)  publicize  the  results  to  related  agencies  and 
stakeholders. 
 
3.  The TA will require about 34 person-months of consulting services (4 international and 
30 national) spread over a period of 8 months, including fieldwork. The international consultants 
will provide expertise in ITS. The national consultants will have expertise in (i) road planning; (ii) 
ITS, especially system architecture; (iii) road and traffic information database; and (iv) transport 
standard/regulation. One of the national experts will be the team leader and an international 
consultant will be the deputy team leader. The international ITS expert will cover the above four 
areas. The international consultant must be a graduate of transport engineering/planning or its 
equivalent, with 15 years of practical experience in transport planning and ITS. The national 
consultants for road planning, ITS especially system architecture, road and traffic information 
database,  and  transport  standard/regulation  must  be  a  graduate  of  transport 
engineering/planning or its equivalent, with 10 years of practical experience.  
 
B.  Consultants 
 
1.  Road Planning (0.5 person-month international, 4.0 person-months national) 
 
4.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Survey and analyze transport planning related to ITS in the PRC. The tasks 
include, but will not be limited to (a) reviewing existing strategies, policies, and 
development  programs  of  ITS  technology;  and  (b) reviewing  key  issues  and 
problems.  
 
(ii)  Support the establishment of the standard architecture framework of TISS. The 
framework  will  cover  the  following  major  elements:  (a)  information  service 
including,  but  not  limited  to  basic  information  service  concerning  road 
infrastructure; traffic information; traffic meteorological service; road condition 
information  service;  bus  ticket  booking  and  sales  service;  tourist  traffic 
information  service;  vehicle  maintenance  and  emergency  rescue  information 
service; other transport information services; travel path planning information 
service; and inquiry, consultation, and complaints; (b) service measures including, 
but not limited to travel information service through website, call center (hotline), 
short message, changeable message sign, traffic radio broadcast, and booklets; 
and (c) system implementation and operation including, but not be limited to

mechanism, service free of charge, and commercialized operation. 
 
(iii)  Support the establishment of implementing and operating guidelines for TISS, 
including but not limited to (a) TISS architecture framework; (b) planning and 
organization; (c) implementation and operation procedures; (d) system service 
measures; (e) key components of hardware and software; (f) data collection, 
input, processing, communication; (g) information service measures and quality 
control; and (h) performance monitoring and evaluation.  
 
2.  Intelligent Transport Systems (2.0 person-months international, 14.0 person- 
months national) 
 
5.  The consultants will undertake these tasks. 
 
(i)  Survey and analyze the current status of ITS in the PRC. The survey includes, 
but  will  not  be  limited  to  reviewing  (a)  existing  strategies,  policies,  and 
development  programs  of  ITS  technology;  (b)  current  research  on  and 
development of ITS activities, application, pilot, and demonstration projects; (c) 
related laws, regulations, institutions, and standards; and (d) key issues and 
problems in the current practice of ITS and TISS. 
 
(ii)  Identify key issues on the TISS architecture framework. The task includes, but will 
not be limited to (a) policy, regulatory, institutional issues; (b) technical issues 
including  existing  transport  data  system,  and  communication  system;  (c) 
coordination beyond provinces; and (d) user demand. 
 
(iii)  Review systems similar to TISS in developed countries. The task includes, but 
will not be limited to reviewing (a) development policy, strategy, and government 
function;  (b)  the  design  architecture  framework;  (c)  necessary  hardware  and 
software;  and  (iv)  development  mechanism  and  related  laws,  regulations, 
institutions, and standards. 
 
(iv)  Prepare recommendations for PRC’s ITS and TISS. 
 
(v)  Establish  the  standard  architecture  framework  of  TISS  covering  these  major 
elements: (a) information service including, but not limited to basic information 
service concerning road infrastructure, traffic information, traffic meteorological 
service, road condition information service, bus ticket booking and sales service, 
tourist traffic information service, vehicle maintenance and emergency rescue 
information  service,  other  transport  information  service,  travel  path  planning 
information  service,  and  inquiry,  consultation,  and  complaints;  (b)  service 
measures including, but not limited to travel information service through website, 
call  center  (hotline),  short  message,  changeable  message  sign,  traffic  radio 
broadcast, and booklets; and (c) system implementation and operation including 
but not limited to centralized or decentralized system, information exchange and 
communication  mechanism,  service  free  of  charge,  and  commercialized 
operation. 
 
(vi)  Establish the implementing and operating guidelines for TISS, including but not 
limited to (a) TISS architecture framework; (b) planning and organization; (c) 
implementing and operating procedures; (d) system service measures; (e) key

program  for  the  executing  agency  and  carry  out  capacity  building  through 
workshops and training program; and publicize the results to related agencies 
and stakeholders.

7.  The consultants’ tasks are as follows. 
 
(i)  Survey and analyze the current status of ITS standard/regulation in the PRC. The 
task includes, but will not be limited to reviewing (a) related laws, regulations, 
institutions, and standards; and (ii) key issues and problems. 
 
(ii)  Identify key issues on TISS architecture framework including, but not limited to (a) 
policy, regulatory institutional issues; and (b) coordination beyond provinces. 
 
(iii)  Help establish the standard architecture framework of TISS covering these major 
elements: (a) information service including, but not be limited to basic information 
service concerning road infrastructure, traffic information, traffic meteorological 
service, road condition information service, bus ticket booking and sales service, 
tourist traffic information service, vehicle maintenance and emergency rescue 
information  service,  other  transport  information  service,  travel  path  planning 
information  service,  and  inquiry,  consultation,  and  complaints;  (b)  service 
measures including, but not limited to travel information service through website, 
call  center  (hotline),  short  message,  changeable  message  sign,  traffic  radio 
broadcast and booklet; and (c) system implementation and operation including, 
but not limited to centralized or decentralized system, information exchange and 
communication  mechanism,  service  free  of  charge,  and  commercialized 
operation. 
 
(iv)  Help establish the implementing and operating guidelines for TISS including, but 
not limited to (a) TISS architecture framework; (b) planning and organization; (c) 
implementation and operation procedures; (d) system service measures; (e) key 
components of hardware and software; (f) data collection, input, processing, 
communication; (g) information service measures and quality control; and (h) 
performance monitoring and evaluation.  
 
(v)  Carry out a workshop to consult stakeholders at the beginning of the TA and 
another workshop to disseminate the outputs and increase awareness, prepare a 
training program for MOC and build its capacity through workshops and a training 
program; and publicize the results to related agencies and stakeholders. 
 
C.  Reports and Workshops 
 
8.  The consultants will submit the following reports to the Asian Development Bank and 
MOC: (i) list of the sources of information, related regulations, related organizations and contact 
persons; outlines of case studies; and outline of the final report (month 1); (ii) issues identified 
so far, potential recommendations and suggestions on the standard architecture framework and 
implementing/operating  guidelines  (month  2);  (iii)  review  of  the  current  status  of  the  PRC 
(months 1–2); (iv) identification of the current issues in the PRC (months 1–3); (v) review of 
international experience (months 1–4); (vi) inception report including an outline of the final 
report a domestic and overseas training program (month 2); (vii) holding of the national and 
international training (months 4–8); (viii) interim report (month 4); (ix) draft standard architecture 
framework and implementing/operating guidelines (month 6); (x) prepared standard architecture 
framework and implementing/operating guidelines (month 7); (xi) final report (month 7); (xii)
